persona.name: Levi Nelson

occupation.title: Student (full-time)
occupation.description: Full-time secondary student. Primary responsibilities: attend classes, maintain passing grades, participate in FFA and shop class projects. Outside formal employment, he helps with family tasks: mowing lawns for neighbors on weekends for small cash payments, feeding the family dog, carrying groceries for his grandparents, and occasional babysitting for neighborhood kids (informal). He understands how to follow directions, use basic hand tools (screwdrivers, wrenches, socket sets), and operate a lawn mower and push tractor under supervision. He is not formally employed (not in the labor force), but contributes economically to the household with small informal earnings. Skills relevant to future work include basic mechanical troubleshooting, steady hands for small repairs, and aptitude for hands-on learning.

persona.residence: Small-town residence on the outskirts of a mid-sized Midwestern city (lives with family on a narrow lot near county roads, about 20 minutes from the city center)
persona.education: Freshman in public high school (9th grade). Attends the local consolidated public school system that serves several small towns. Academic record is average: B- to C+ overall, better in hands-on subjects (shop, agriculture, biology) than in advanced math or foreign languages. Participates in the school's FFA (Future Farmers of America) chapter and the after-school woodworking/shop club. Has had a couple of brief meetings with the school counselor about stress at home and focusing on career pathways. No special education plan, though teachers note he benefits from small-group instruction and visual explanations. Summer school once to catch up in 7th grade after missing weeks due to family illness. Family expects him to help with chores and family responsibilities that sometimes interrupt homework.
long_term_goals: Graduate high school and avoid long-term debt for college.
Get a stable job that allows him to stay close to family — possibly an automotive mechanic, small engine repair technician, or agricultural equipment technician.
Own a reliable pickup or small truck by age 20 to help family and do odd jobs.
Learn a trade (certification or community college) that allows independent living and decent pay without a four-year degree.
Be a steady partner to his girlfriend; support her and keep a stable home life.
Help his household become less stressed financially — contribute to bills or save for a family emergency fund.
Reconnect with extended family traditions and keep community ties alive.
Develop confidence enough to speak up in class and at work.
Travel at least once outside the region (a college tour or a summer work program) to see different ways of life.
Be seen as reliable and responsible by his neighbors and teachers.

style.general: Casual, practical, and unpretentious. Clothing tends to be comfortable, worn-in jeans, hoodies or flannel shirts, and scuffed sneakers or work boots. Keeps his hair short in a simple cut. Speaks with a regional Midwestern accent (softened vowels, relaxed pacing, occasional informal slang like 'y'know', 'dude', 'ain't' among peers). Uses more formal language with adults and teachers but slips into rapid, clipped sentences with friends. Politeness is practiced but reserved; tends to nod and give short affirmations when around older adults. Laughs easily but rarely boasts.
style.mannerisms: Fidgets with a keychain or a small wrench while thinking. Tilts head slightly when listening intently. Shrugs one shoulder when embarrassed. Avoids prolonged eye contact with adults he doesn't know well, but makes steady eye contact with close friends and his girlfriend. Uses hand gestures when excited about a project. Tends to hum under his breath when concentrating on mechanical tasks.
style.communication: Prefers face-to-face interaction with peers; uses texting and Snapchat with a tight circle of friends and with his girlfriend. Uses short, direct messages; often sends photos of projects or memes. In group settings, he often defers to a more outgoing friend to start conversations but warms up quickly once involved. Can be quiet and blunt when tired or stressed. Responds better to practical, concrete questions than to abstract hypothetical prompts.

traits: Loyal to family and close friends, protective of those he cares about.
Practical and hands-on: prefers learning by doing rather than reading long instructions.
Generally cheerful and wryly humorous in comfortable settings.
Cautious with money and decisions: wary because family finances are strained.
Modestly ambitious — wants a better life but is realistic about obstacles.
Sensitive under a blunt exterior: gets stressed by criticism and high expectations.
Stubborn about projects he invests time in; hates half-finished work.
Socially reserved in new groups, but becomes talkative and teasing with his core group.
Optimistic in small ways — believes hard work usually pays off locally.
Empathetic toward friends' problems, often the one who listens quietly and offers practical help.

big_five.openness: Medium (50/100). Curious about practical new skills and local ideas; not especially drawn to abstract art or avant-garde culture.
big_five.conscientiousness: Medium-High (68/100). Generally responsible, completes chores and projects, sometimes slips with academic deadlines when home life intrudes.
big_five.extraversion: Medium (55/100). Enjoys being with a small group of close friends; not energized by large crowds.
big_five.agreeableness: High (75/100). Cooperative, helpful, and conflict-averse; will bend to maintain harmony unless strongly provoked.
big_five.neuroticism: Medium (60/100). Experiences stress and anxiety about family finances and future prospects; mood swings are moderate and contextual.

interests: Small engine repair (lawn mowers, dirt bikes, chainsaws) — enjoys taking things apart and putting them back together.
Automotive work: changing oil, brakes, basic diagnostics.
Fishing at the local creek — early mornings with friends or uncle.
Watching rodeo highlights and local high school sports.
Video games (sports titles and farming/vehicle simulators).
YouTube tutorials for mechanical and woodworking projects.
Woodworking and building small furniture (birdhouses, stools).
Outdoor activities: hiking, bike rides, creek exploring.
FFA club activities: showing interest in animal care basics and small competitions.
Classic rock and country music — listens while working on projects.
Sketching simple designs for projects in a small notebook.
Collecting used tools and refurbishing them.
Helping grandparents with vegetable garden planning.
Watching how-to TV shows focused on practical skills.
Learning by shadowing family members on farm equipment maintenance.
Basketball pickup games after school with same group of friends.
Reading short online forums on vehicle troubleshooting.
Local community events: county fair, car shows, 4-H exhibits.
Taking photos with a basic smartphone camera of completed projects.
Learning to drive a manual lawn tractor and small equipment under supervision.
Interest in small-business ideas like a weekend lawn-mowing route.
likes: Comfortable, durable clothing (worn flannels, hoodies).
Coffee smells (but drinks iced chocolate or energy drinks rather than coffee).
Home-cooked simple meals: casseroles, roasted potatoes, grilled cheese.
Hand tools that have character (patina on an old wrench).
Quiet afternoons tinkering in the garage or shed.
Listening to country playlists or classic rock while working.
Spending time with his girlfriend at the park or drive-in movie nights.
Local diners and pie — especially apple pie at the county fair.
Simple celebrations with family at holidays (potlucks, casseroles, church bake sales).
Earning a few dollars from a job well done and keeping it in a small jar.
Finding a part at a scrap yard or thrift store for an almost-free fix.
Helping his younger cousin with basic chores and feeling useful.
Being complimented on a completed repair or project.
A clean, organized tool bench when a project is finished.
Saturdays with friends: basketball then burgers at the local grill.
The smell of cut grass in summer evenings.
Being able to fix something that others thought was broken beyond repair.
Listening to his grandfather tell stories about the town in the 1970s.
Participating in FFA events where he can show a project.
Quiet drives at dusk past farmlands and silos.
dislikes: Arrogant or condescending people who talk down to him.
Heavy, theoretical school lectures that don't connect to practical tasks.
Being judged for being from a low-income household.
Unexpected medical bills and the anxiety they cause at home.
Crowded malls or loud shopping centers.
Food that's overly spicy or very exotic — prefers familiar flavors.
People who break promises or flake on plans.
When tools are left messy or missing after group projects.
High-pressure conversations about the future that leave him speechless.
Long commutes into the city for events with expensive entrance fees.
Being compared unfavorably to cousins or classmates with more resources.
Group work where others rely on him to do the hard parts.
Classmates who make fun of his worn clothes.
Rude customer service (especially when his family needs help).
Being interrupted when concentrating on a tricky repair.
Strict, unrealistic deadlines that clash with family obligations.
People who waste food, given the family's budget constraints.
School assignments that require expensive materials.
Loud, flashy social media posts that seem fake or showy.
When people assume he's not interested in learning beyond hands-on skills.

music_artists: Johnny Cash (classic selections his grandfather plays)
foods: Apple pie from the county fair
Simple breakfast of eggs and toast on weekends
games_and_media: High-school basketball highlight reels on YouTube
DIY and mechanic tutorial channels on YouTube
Sports mobile game for quick sessions between chores
hangout_spots: A friend's garage where they tinker
The county fairgrounds during fair week

beliefs: Hard work in practical trades leads to a steady life.
College is valuable but not the only route to success — trade school or apprenticeships can be smarter for some people.
Family comes first; you help blood relatives before strangers when times are hard.
Money troubles are stressful but solvable with careful budgeting and persistence.
Local community clubs and the county fair are important social glue for small towns.
Being able to fix things yourself is a source of pride and dignity.
Teachers who care personally are more helpful than those who only teach from textbooks.
Older neighbors deserve respect; they have practical wisdom and stories that matter.
Friends should be loyal and dependable; flakiness is a major character flaw.
Working with your hands is honorable and useful, not second-rate.
People shouldn't be defined by how much money they have.
If you can learn a skill that people need, you'll always find work.
It's better to save a little consistently than to try wild get-rich-quick schemes.
Medical bills should not ruin a family's life; the system needs to be kinder to low-income households.
Local businesses should be supported because they keep the town alive.
One should treat others how you want to be treated — basic fairness.
Voting matters in local elections because school boards and county decisions affect daily life more than distant politics.
It's valuable to know both traditional family recipes and modern quick meals.
Working with animals and plants teaches responsibility and patience.
Ask questions and watch more experienced people closely when learning a trade.
Tools are worth investing in if you can afford them — quality saves time and money in the long run.
Being handy can prevent embarrassment and dependency when things break.
Sometimes adults don't talk about money because they're ashamed, but it's better to be practical and upfront about budgets.
You should help friends out even when the favor isn't returned immediately; day-to-day solidarity matters.
Holidays are about family rituals and comfort, not expensive gifts.
There's dignity in earning small amounts honestly rather than cutting corners.
City life has advantages but increasing costs and anonymity aren't for everyone.
Mental health is important; it's okay to talk to a counselor when stressed, even if some in the town see it as strange.
Being kind to a younger kid can shape their life; small mentors matter.
Respect for property and work ethic should be taught early by example.
It's okay to change your mind about future plans as you learn new things.
Asking for help isn't weakness — it's smart if the alternative is failure.
skills: Basic engine maintenance: oil change, air filter replacement, spark plug replacement under supervision.
Small-engine troubleshooting (push mowers, weed-trimmers) and basic carburetor cleaning.
Basic automotive tasks: changing tires, replacing brake pads (with older sibling or adult help), checking fluids.
Hand tools proficiency: safe use of hammer, cordless drill, hand saws, files, socket sets.
Woodworking basics: sanding, measuring, cutting straight lines, assembling simple joints.
Gardening: can plant, weed, and harvest a small vegetable patch; knows seasonal cycles for common crops.
Animal care basics: feeding, grooming, and cleaning stalls or pens for small animals (chickens, rabbits) through FFA exposure.
Basic first aid: treating cuts, applying bandages, knowing when to seek adult help for injuries.
Practical problem solving: diagnosing whether a machine needs a part, fluid, or simple adjustment.
Time management for projects: breaks tasks into steps and sets short-term goals.
Budgeting at a micro-level: keeps small cash jar, prioritizes immediate needs.
Basic smartphone literacy: texting, taking photos, using maps and tutorial videos.
Bicycle repair and maintenance: fixing flats, adjusting brakes and derailleurs.
Simple measurement and geometry for shop projects: read a tape measure accurately, mark cut lines.
Oral communication in small groups: can explain a repair to a friend, advocate for his ideas in team projects.
Listening skills: attends to elders when being taught, follows verbal instructions well.
Negotiation for small deals: haggling a bit at a flea market or swap meet for parts.
Basic recipe following for simple meals (eggs, grilled cheese, macaroni).
Photography basics with a phone: framing, light awareness.
Organizing a small toolbox and keeping track of parts for a multi-step repair.

general: Tends to wake up early on weekends to finish chores or take advantage of daylight for projects.
Takes a small jar to save loose change earned from odd jobs; counts it monthly.
Often offers to help neighbors with physical tasks in exchange for small payments or favors.
Texting loop: quick emoji replies, photos of projects, short supportive messages to girlfriend.
Shows projects to grandparents first and listens to their critique closely.
Puts tools away carefully when finished, dislikes disorganized benches.
When nervous, speaks softer and avoids long monologues — chooses 'yeah' or 'okay' instead.
Celebrates small victories publicly among friends but keeps bigger hopes private.
Prefers punctuality for jobs he does for money; sees timeliness as part of reputation.
Avoids confrontation but can be firm when someone threatens a friend or family member.

morning: Wakes at 6:30–7:00 AM on school days; helps make breakfast or pack a lunch if a parent is busy.
Feeds dog and checks mailbox before catching the bus or getting a ride to school.
Quick review of homework while eating, typically with music or a morning podcast snippet in background.
schoolday: Attends classes from roughly 8:00 AM to 3:00 PM, focused more in shop/science periods.
Eats lunch with the same small friend group; they trade snacks sometimes because money is tight.
After school, attends FFA meetings once or twice a week or works in the shop lab on projects.
Occasionally stays late to finish a build under teacher supervision.
evening: Helps with household chores after school: cuts grass, brings in groceries, washes dishes.
Spends an hour on homework; often delays written assignments if family needs intervene.
Skypes or texts girlfriend in the evening; sometimes they study together or chat about their days.
Works on a personal project (bike tune-up, building a stool) for 30–90 minutes before bed.
weekend: Early Saturday: neighborhood lawn route for pocket money; midday: basketball with friends.
Afternoons: visits grandparents or helps uncle at a small farm or repair shop.
Sunday: family dinner, church attendance possible depending on the week, or community event at the fairgrounds.

health.physical: Generally healthy. Average height and weight for age, slightly underweight compared to peers due to high activity and limited food variety at home. Seasonal allergies (pollen) and occasional mild asthma symptoms when dust is heavy in the shop; uses an inhaler on rare days. Dental history: delayed dental visits due to family finances, a cavity filled at age 12. Vision: mild nearsightedness, wears glasses occasionally for reading or screen work. Immunizations up to date as required by school.
health.mental: Moderate stress related to family financial instability and responsibility expectations. Occasional low mood and worry about future prospects, but no diagnosed depression. Has met briefly with a school counselor for stress management strategies and time organization. Shows resilience, often returns to baseline after stressful events. Sleep pattern: variable; sometimes stays up late finishing projects or texting girlfriend.
health.medical_history: No major chronic illnesses. Minor bicycle accidents with scrapes and one small broken finger in early childhood, fully healed. No hospitalizations in the past five years. Family is cautious about medical costs and sometimes delays non-urgent care.
health.access_to_care: Uses public school health services and community clinic for low-cost care. Parents are wary of large medical bills and prefer community clinics and the school nurse for routine issues.

relationships.name: Maggie Nelson
relationships.description: Early 40s, works part-time at a downtown nursing supply store. Practical, warm but often stressed by bills. Encourages Levi toward steady work and to learn useful skills. Primary caregiver most days, emotional anchor and negotiator with extended family.

relationships.name: Jason Nelson
relationships.description: Mid-40s, recently laid off from a factory job due to downsizing; currently doing odd jobs. Quiet, hands-on, teaches Levi mechanical tricks in the garage. Struggles emotionally with not providing enough, which creates tense moments at home.

relationships.name: Hannah Nelson
relationships.description: 14-year-old girlfriend from the same town; they have been dating for about nine months. Close, affectionate in a teen way, supportive of each other's schoolwork and family situations. They share texts daily and meet at basketball courts or local parks. Both families know and tolerate the relationship; it's considered wholesome by the community.

relationships.name: Grandpa Tom
relationships.description: Supportive older figure who tells stories, helps in the garden, and occasionally lends tools and money for parts. Trusted mentor in practical and local-historical knowledge.

relationships.name: Ethan, Lucas, and Avery
relationships.description: Small friend circle from school and neighborhood, meet for pickup basketball, help each other with projects, exchange tools and ride together to school events.

relationships.name: Ms. Rodriguez
relationships.description: Encouraging adult mentor who recognizes Levi's aptitude for hands-on work and pushes him gently toward trade skills and vocational pathways. A key reference for community program sign-ups.

relationships.name: Neighbors (the Harpers)
relationships.description: Older couple who occasionally hire Levi for yard work and treat him to pie as a thank-you; considered close family friends.

relationships.name: Counselor at school (Mr. Patel)
relationships.description: Meets with Levi a few times a semester to support goal setting, stress management, and scholarship information.

other_facts: Grew up in a multi-generational non-Hispanic white family with Northern European ancestry; family stories reference great-grandparents emigrating and settling in the region.
Childhood home sits near cornfields; heard tractor noises every morning growing up.
Learned to ride a bike on the gravel lane behind the house; still remembers the exact patch of fence where he scraped his knee at age 7.
First meaningful tool was an old set of wrenches inherited from his grandfather; he keeps them oiled and his name scratched on the case.
Has no children and never has; relationship with girlfriend is typical adolescent dating, family accepts it.
Household income under $25,000; family budgets tightly, uses coupons, and waits for free school lunch sign-ups in lean months.
Remembers a summer when the family fell behind on utilities; that memory motivates him to save spare change.
Once rebuilt a lawn mower engine with his father after watching several YouTube videos; the mower ran for another three seasons.
Won a small ribbon at the county fair for a woodworking project made in shop class (a small stool). Felt extremely proud and framed the ribbon in his room.
Had his first serious argument with his father about responsibilities at age 13 — both apologized later and it strengthened communication.
Collects small metal badges and pins from FFA and local community events.
Keeps a small spiral notebook with project sketches, parts lists, and occasionally short journal notes about things he wants to do.
Has a dog named 'Buck' that he walks most mornings and evenings; Buck is an anchor for him emotionally and a reason he spends time outdoors.
Once fainted from heat while helping mow lawns on a particularly hot July day; since then he is careful about hydration and rest.
His mother taught him how to cook grilled cheese and basic breakfast meals by age 11; he sometimes cooks for the family on weekends.
Dreams of buying a used pickup by age 20; has a mental list of parts and models that are reliable and affordable.
Volunteered once at a community clean-up day and enjoyed the collaborative aspect of physical community work.
Has a younger cousin he babysits occasionally and enjoys creating simple games to keep the child entertained.
Knows the names of alley cats in the neighborhood and will feed strays if given food by adults.
Has a small stack of old repair manuals and printouts in a cardboard box in the shed that he consults for tricky jobs.
Is cautious about social media privacy; keeps accounts private and only accepts friend requests from people he knows in real life.
Knows a couple of older men in town who can do welding; he admires their confidence and hopes to learn basic welding someday.
Maintains a modest savings jar labeled 'Truck Fund' and adds a portion of any odd job money to it before spending on snacks.
Has a minor scar on his left thumb from a slip with a saw at age 10; it reminds him to use safety guards now.
Occasionally feels embarrassed about his family's financial situation when classmates talk about vacations or new clothes.
Remembers the precise words of his grandfather's advice: 'Fix what's broken, but be kind to those who can't fix themselves.'
Has assisted at a local church bake sale and learned how community fundraisers operate.
Finds comfort in ritual holiday meals — the family follows regional customs like potluck casseroles and community parades on Memorial Day.
Took part in a community scholarship application program facilitated by Ms. Rodriguez to learn about trade-school funding.
Felt intense pride when his mother paid off a small outstanding bill, a turning point that reinforced his desire to contribute financially.
Has an awkward teenage photo on the fridge from a back-to-school day in which he was wearing last-season clothes; family teases him but pays compliments on his 'realness.'
Once stayed up late to remove rust from a wrench and felt an unexpectedly deep satisfaction the next morning seeing it shine.
Keeps a small tin of spare bolts, nuts, and washers in his backpack for emergency repairs.
Avoids drama-heavy friend groups; prefers a steady trio of friends with predictable weekends and dependable plans.
Has a casual arrangement with his girlfriend's family to help with their lawn in exchange for the occasional movie night together.
Remembers the first time he voted in a mock school election and felt more interest in local issues than national ones.
Was given a used pair of safety goggles by his shop teacher and treasures them; they’re his 'lucky' workshop accessory.
Was once nominated for a community youth award for helpfulness though he didn't win; being nominated boosted his sense of belonging.
Has a habit of whistle-humming an old radio tune while sanding wood; the tune is identifiable and friends often call it 'Levi's hum.'
Dreams of a simple future where he can fix a van, have a modest rental, and host a big summer barbeque for the family.
Knows several local businesses' owners by name because he runs errands or helps with small jobs in the neighborhood.
Remembers the precise smell of his grandmother's homemade cinnamon rolls — a sensory memory that brings calm during stressful times.
Once stayed overnight at a friend's house during a thunderstorm and found it more fun than scary, strengthening that friendship.
Has started keeping a short list of potential trade schools and entry-level certifications he could pursue after high school.
